question: Beyond CBD, which commonly prescribed drugs or their metabolites interact with VDAC at therapeutically relevant concentrations? (1) Valproic acid is a known hepatotoxin and mitochondrial modulator — does it engage VDAC1? (2) Acetaminophen toxicity involves mitochondrial dysfunction — is VDAC part of the NAPQI damage cascade? (3) Metformin accumulates in mitochondria and inhibits Complex I — does it also modulate VDAC gating? (4) Statins (particularly lipophilic ones like atorvastatin) partition into membranes — is VDAC occupancy a hidden variable in statin-associated myopathy? (5) What is the predicted VDAC interaction landscape for the top 20 most prescribed drugs with known mitochondrial effects?

gate.recommendation: Lab Gate PASSED with filter. 19/20 claims cleared. 1 filtered: 'Lipophilic statins (e.g., atorvastatin) are low-af...' not feasible

hypotheses.prediction: IF purified human VDAC1 is reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers and exposed to valproic acid (50–700 µM), THEN single-channel open probability (Po) will shift by ≥15% relative to vehicle, with an EC50 between 100–500 µM.

IF primary mouse hepatocytes or HepaRG cells are exposed to hepatotoxic APAP concentrations (5–20 mM), THEN LC-MS/MS of immunoprecipitated VDAC1 will reveal NAPQI adducts (mass shift +149.05 Da) on Cys127 and/or Cys232 in ≥60% of biological replicates, with adduct abundance correlating with APAP dose (Spearman ρ > 0.7).

IF VDAC1 is reconstituted in bilayers pre-doped with atorvastatin or simvastatin at membrane concentrations equivalent to myopathic tissue exposure (1–10 µM bulk, yielding ~100–1000 µM membrane concentration given logP ~4), THEN VDAC1 conductance will decrease by ≥20% and voltage-dependent closure will shift by ≥5 mV (V₀ shift), compared to cholesterol-only membranes.

IF purified VDAC1 is exposed to metformin (0.01–10 mM) in reconstituted bilayers, THEN no change in conductance or gating will be observed (ΔPo < 5%, Δconductance < 10%); HOWEVER, in intact mitochondria, metformin (1–10 mM) will reduce VDAC-dependent metabolite flux (ATP/ADP exchange measured by luciferase) by ≥30%, an effect abolished by Δψm clamping with FCCP.

protocols.prediction: IF purified human VDAC1 is reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers and exposed to valproic acid (50–700 µM), THEN single-channel open probability (Po) will shift by ≥15% relative to vehicle, with an EC50 between 100–500 µM.
protocols.protocol: Reconstitute purified recombinant hVDAC1 (E. coli expression, refolded in LDAO) into DPhPC planar bilayers using the painting method. Record single-channel currents at ±30 mV under voltage-clamp before and after sequential VPA additions (10, 50, 100, 300, 700, 1000 µM) to the cis chamber. Analyze Po, conductance substates, and gating kinetics across ≥5 independent bilayers per condition. Timeline: 6–8 weeks.
controls: Vehicle (equivalent Na⁺ addition as sodium valproate)
protocols.expected_outcome: VPA at 100–700 µM shifts Po by >15%, likely toward open state (fatty acid analog behavior), with
protocols.null_outcome: No statistically significant change in Po, conductance, or gating kinetics at any VPA concentration up to 1 mM across ≥5 bilayers (p > 0.05, paired t-test).

protocols.prediction: IF primary mouse hepatocytes or HepaRG cells are exposed to hepatotoxic APAP concentrations (5–20 mM), THEN LC-MS/MS of immunoprecipitated VDAC1 will reveal NAPQI adducts (mass shift +149.05 Da) on Cys127 and/or Cys232 in ≥60% of biological replicates, with adduct abundance correlating with APAP dose (Spearman ρ > 0.7).
protocols.protocol: Treat HepaRG cells (CYP2E1-competent) with APAP (1, 5, 10, 20 mM) for 2, 6, and 12 h. Isolate mitochondria by differential centrifugation, immunoprecipitate VDAC1 (anti-VDAC1 ab15895), digest with trypsin/chymotrypsin, and analyze by nanoLC-MS/MS (Orbitrap) with targeted PRM for Cys127/Cys232-containing peptides ± 149.05 Da modification. Parallel: BSO pre-treatment (GSH depletion) and NAC co-treatment arms. Timeline: 10–12 weeks.
controls: NAPQI direct addition to isolated mitochondria (cell-free positive control)
protocols.expected_outcome: NAPQI adducts detected on Cys232 (most accessible) at ≥5 mM APAP by 6 h, increasing with
protocols.null_outcome: No NAPQI adducts detected on any VDAC1 cysteine at any dose/timepoint despite confirmed adducts on known targets (GAPDH, GST), indicating VDAC1 cysteines are not preferentially modified by NAPQI in situ.

protocols.prediction: IF VDAC1 is reconstituted in bilayers pre-doped with atorvastatin or simvastatin at membrane concentrations equivalent to myopathic tissue exposure (1–10 µM bulk, yielding ~100–1000 µM membrane concentration given logP ~4), THEN VDAC1 conductance will decrease by ≥20% and voltage-dependent closure will shift by ≥5 mV (V₀ shift), compared to cholesterol-only membranes.
protocols.protocol: Reconstitute hVDAC1 in DPhPC/cholesterol (80:20) planar bilayers. Pre-incubate lipid mixtures with atorvastatin, simvastatin, or pravastatin (hydrophilic control) at 0.1, 1, 5, 10, 50 µM before bilayer formation. Record multichannel and single-channel I-V curves from -60 to +60 mV in 5 mV steps. Calculate G-V curves, V₀, and gating charge. Compare statin-doped vs. vehicle-doped membranes. Confirm membrane incorporation by fluorescence anisotropy (DPH). Timeline: 8–10 weeks.
readouts: statin membrane concentration (LC-MS of bilayer lipid extract)
protocols.expected_outcome: Atorvastatin and simvastatin (logP ~4–5) shift V₀ leftward by 5–15 mV and reduce maximal conductance by 20–40% at ≥5 µM bulk concentration, consistent with altered bilayer mechanics. Pravastatin (logP ~−0.8) shows no effect. Effect magnitude correlates with membrane statin content.
protocols.null_outcome: No significant difference in conductance, V₀, or gating parameters between statin-doped and

protocols.prediction: IF purified VDAC1 is exposed to metformin (0.01–10 mM) in reconstituted bilayers, THEN no change in conductance or gating will be observed (ΔPo < 5%, Δconductance < 10%); HOWEVER, in intact mitochondria, metformin (1–10 mM) will reduce VDAC-dependent metabolite flux (ATP/ADP exchange measured by luciferase) by ≥30%, an effect abolished by Δψm clamping with FCCP.

final_claims.statement: Valproic acid modulates VDAC1 indirectly — it alters VDAC expression and oligomerization state via effects on cardiolipin and ceramide metabolism — but no direct high-affinity binding (Kd < 50 µM) has been demonstrated.
final_claims.mechanism: VPA disrupts fatty acid β-oxidation, alters mitochondrial membrane lipid composition, shifting VDAC gating indirectly rather than through pore occupancy.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Bilayer electrophysiology showing VPA directly modulates VDAC conductance at <100 µM in purified reconstituted system.

final_claims.statement: NAPQI interacts with VDAC1 via covalent modification of exposed cysteine residue(s) (Cys127, Cys232), contributing to mitochondrial permeability transition during acetaminophen toxicity.
final_claims.mechanism: NAPQI is a potent electrophile that modifies protein thiols; VDAC1 has solvent-accessible cysteines in the channel wall; thiol modification is known to shift VDAC gating to closed state.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Mass spectrometry of VDAC from APAP-treated hepatocyte mitochondria showing no NAPQI adducts on VDAC cysteines.

final_claims.statement: Metformin at mitochondrial matrix concentrations (estimated 1–10 mM due to membrane-potential-driven accumulation) likely modulates VDAC gating from the intermembrane space side, but published direct binding data are absent.
final_claims.mechanism: Metformin is a cationic biguanide that accumulates ~1000× in mitochondria; VDAC voltage-sensing is charge-sensitive; high local concentrations could alter channel selectivity.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Planar bilayer recordings with metformin titration showing no effect on VDAC conductance up to 10 mM.

final_claims.statement: Lipophilic statins (atorvastatin, simvastatin; logP >4) partition into the outer mitochondrial membrane at sufficient concentrations to alter VDAC-lipid interactions and gating, representing a plausible contributor to statin myopathy.
final_claims.mechanism: Membrane-partitioned statins alter bilayer properties (thickness, curvature) around VDAC, modifying voltage-dependent gating similar to cholesterol modulation of VDAC.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: No difference in VDAC conductance in membranes doped with atorvastatin at membrane concentrations equivalent to therapeutic exposure.

final_claims.statement: A systematic VDAC interaction landscape for the top 20 mitochondrially-active drugs does not currently exist in published literature; predicted occupancy ranking would place lipophilic weak acids/bases with membrane-partitioning coefficients >100 as highest-risk.
final_claims.mechanism: No systematic screen has been published; this is a gap, not a finding.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Discovery of a published systematic VDAC-drug interaction screen covering ≥10 common drugs. ───

final_claims.statement: Valproic acid (VPA) engages VDAC1 at therapeutically relevant concentrations (Cmax ~500–700 µM).
final_claims.mechanism: VPA’s anionic amphiphilic structure may bind VDAC1’s voltage-sensing N-terminal domain, altering gating and Ca²⁺ flux (mimicking CBD’s effect).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: VDAC1 knockout in hepatocytes abolishes VPA-induced mitochondrial depolarization or swelling.

final_claims.statement: NAPQI (acetaminophen metabolite) covalently modifies VDAC1 cysteines, contributing to mitochondrial permeability transition (MPT) pore opening.
final_claims.mechanism: NAPQI’s electrophilic quinoneimine reacts with VDAC1’s Cys127/Cys232, disrupting β-barrel stability and promoting MPT.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Mass spectrometry fails to detect NAPQI-VDAC1 adducts in vivo, or VDAC1 cysteine mutants resist acetaminophen toxicity.

final_claims.statement: Metformin does not directly modulate VDAC gating but may indirectly alter VDAC conductance via Complex I inhibition and Δψm collapse.
final_claims.mechanism: Metformin’s cationic accumulation in mitochondria depolarizes Δψm, reducing VDAC’s voltage-dependent gating without direct binding.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Metformin binds VDAC1 in surface plasmon resonance (SPR) or microscale thermophoresis (MST) assays (Kd < 1 mM).

final_claims.statement: Lipophilic statins (e.g., atorvastatin) occupy VDAC1 at concentrations linked to myopathy (Cmax ~0.1–1 µM), competing with cholesterol for membrane microdomains.
final_claims.mechanism: Statins’ planar aromatic rings intercalate into VDAC1’s β-barrel, disrupting anion selectivity and ATP/ADP flux.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: VDAC1 reconstitution in liposomes shows no statin-induced conductance changes at 1 µM.

final_claims.statement: The top 20 mitochondrial-acting drugs’ VDAC interaction likelihood correlates with logP > 3 and pKa < 7.4 (anionic at cytosolic pH).
final_claims.mechanism: Drugs with high logP partition into mitochondrial membranes, increasing VDAC1 encounter probability; anionic charge favors binding to VDAC1’s cationic N-terminus.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: A screen of 20 drugs finds no correlation between logP/pKa and VDAC1 binding affinity. --- ───

final_claims.statement: Valproic acid (VPA) modulates VDAC1 oligomerization and conductance at therapeutic concentrations (~50μM free).
final_claims.mechanism: VPA, an amphipathic carboxylate, binds VDAC1 N-terminal α-helix, disrupting β-barrel stability like nucleotides.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Patch-clamp electrophysiology showing no VPA effect on purified VDAC1 at 10-100μM.

final_claims.statement: NAPQI covalently modifies VDAC1 cysteines in toxicity cascade, potentiating MPT at supratherapeutic acetaminophen doses (>150μg/mL).
final_claims.mechanism: NAPQI arylation of Cys residues alters VDAC1 gating/oligomerization, amplifying ROS/permeability as in MPT pore models.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: LC-MS proteomics of NAPQI-exposed mito lacking VDAC1 adducts.

final_claims.statement: Metformin does not directly engage VDAC1 gating at therapeutic mito concentrations (>>100μM).
final_claims.mechanism: Metformin's polypharmacy on Complex I/ANT lacks structural mimicry to VDAC1 ligands (e.g., no amphipathicity for MOM partition).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: SPR/BLI assay showing metformin Kd <500μM on VDAC1 protein.

final_claims.statement: Lipophilic statins (atorvastatin) occupy VDAC1 at muscle mito concentrations (~1-10μM), contributing to myopathy.
final_claims.mechanism: Atorvastatin's lipophilicity enables MOM insertion, sterically occluding VDAC1 pore like cholesterol.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In silico docking (e.g., AutoDock) scoring atorvastatin < CBD to VDAC1 PDB:3EMN.

final_claims.statement: Among top 20 mito drugs (metformin, atorva, aspirin, omeprazole), predicted VDAC1 interactors at C_eff/TI: VPA >>> aspirin > simvastatin > naproxen; metformin/levothyroxine negligible.
final_claims.mechanism: QSAR: logP>3 + H-bond acceptors correlate with VDAC1 β-sheet binding (CBD analog).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: CETSA shift assay on VDAC1 thermal stability by top 5 candidates. ───

final_claims.statement: Valproic acid (VPA) directly modulates VDAC1, promoting an open state that contributes to its mitochondrial toxicity.
final_claims.mechanism: VPA, a fatty acid anion present at high therapeutic concentrations (300-700 µM), electrostatically and hydrophobically interacts with VDAC1, stabilizing its high-conductance state.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: A reconstituted VDAC1 lipid bilayer system showing no change in channel open probability or conductance in the presence of 500 µM VPA.

final_claims.statement: The reactive acetaminophen metabolite, NAPQI, covalently modifies VDAC1, contributing to the mitochondrial permeability transition and subsequent cell death in overdose.
final_claims.mechanism: Electrophilic NAPQI forms covalent adducts with nucleophilic VDAC1 cysteine residues, causing pathological channel dysregulation that sensitizes the mitochondrial permeability transition pore.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Mass spectrometry of mitochondrial fractions from NAPQI-treated hepatocytes failing to identify VDAC1-NAPQI adducts, while other known targets are modified.

final_claims.statement: Lipophilic statins (e.g., atorvastatin) are low-affinity VDAC modulators, and their accumulation in the outer mitochondrial membrane is a key initiating factor in statin-associated myopathy.
final_claims.mechanism: High local concentrations of the statin in the outer membrane allosterically constrain VDAC's conformation, impairing metabolite flux and triggering downstream mitochondrial stress pathways.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Muscle-specific VDAC1 knockout mice showing complete resistance to statin-induced myopathy despite similar statin accumulation in muscle tissue.

final_claims.statement: Metformin does not directly modulate VDAC gating in a therapeutically meaningful way.
final_claims.mechanism: Metformin's polar, cationic structure and primary localization within the mitochondrial matrix make a direct, high-affinity interaction with the outer membrane VDAC channel unlikely.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Electrophysiology experiments demonstrating a significant shift in VDAC1 gating voltage at metformin concentrations achievable in the intermembrane space (<5 mM). ───

final_claims.statement: Valproic acid and its reactive metabolites likely engage VDAC1, contributing to its hepatotoxicity, given its known induction of mitochondrial permeability transition.
final_claims.mechanism: A reactive metabolite (e.g., 2,4-diene VPA) covalently modifies VDAC cysteine residues, altering its gating and promoting cytochrome c release.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that VPA toxicity is unchanged in VDAC1/3 knockout hepatocytes or that VPA shows no direct binding to purified VDAC at <100 µM.

final_claims.statement: Acetaminophen toxicity (NAPQI) does not primarily involve direct VDAC modulation; its mitochondrial dysfunction is downstream of JNK activation and MPT pore opening.
final_claims.mechanism: NAPQI depletes glutathione and causes oxidative stress, leading to JNK translocation to mitochondria and MPT pore opening via BIM, not direct VDAC blockade.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Showing NAPQI directly binds and inhibits VDAC conductance before JNK activation in isolated mitochondrial experiments.

final_claims.statement: Lipophilic statins (atorvastatin, simvastatin) at high myopathic concentrations partition into the mitochondrial outer membrane and non-specifically disrupt VDAC oligomerization, contributing to myopathy.
final_claims.mechanism: By intercalating into the membrane, they alter lipid-protein interactions critical for VDAC's β-barrel stability and hexokinase-II binding, impairing metabolic coupling.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Finding no change in VDAC conductance or oligomer state in muscle mitochondria exposed to therapeutic (nanomolar) vs. myopathic (micromolar) statin concentrations. ───
